title.narrative: Inter-American Network of Academies of Science Women for Science Meeting
Réunion du groupe de travail Femmes en sciences du Réseau interaméricain des académies des sciences

description.narrative:
This project will support the annual meeting of the Inter-American Network of Academies of Science (IANAS) Women for Science working group to be held in Ottawa, Canada, from September 21-23, 2014.
IANAS is a regional network of 22 academies of sciences that supports cooperation to strengthen science and technology as a tool for advancing research and development, prosperity, and equity in the Americas. Its four active working groups address the urgent challenges for countries throughout the Americas: water, energy, science in schools, and women in science. These issues are more acute in developing countries.
The Women in Science working group works to enhance the status of women scientists in the Americas. It also advises and informs IANAS, its academies, and its programs on gender issues. They do this through -quantifying women's under-representation; -reducing the isolation of women scientists by connecting them through the IANAS website; -highlighting the achievements of women scientists in Latin America and the Caribbean (LAC) by analyzing factors that determine their careers; -summarizing and disseminating policy recommendations; and -creating connections between countries to support an advanced woman scientist from the region to conduct her work in another IANAS country.
The participation of women in science is a central theme for the working group. This year's meeting will widen the scope of the traditional definition of women in science beyond academia to demonstrate the scope of science-related career options available to women.
The project funds will be used to organize a special session that will invite women leading scientific field-building efforts in the Americas to participate on the Internet. Participants will include IDRC grantees: -Carlota Monroy, renowned for her work reducing Chagas disease transmission rates in Guatemala and neighbouring Central American countries; -Juliana Quintero, from Fundación Santa Fé de Bogotá, who is working on dengue control projects throughout Colombia; and -Carolina Trivelli from Peru who will discuss her work on social protection and financial inclusion.
IDRC funding will ensure increased participation from throughout LAC. The grant will also allow the Royal Society of Canada to play a proactive role in the Women for Science group by hosting the event, ensuring stronger participation from the Canadian scientific community.
